content.description: Fire a quick boulder, aiming for a dish up and left, before dancing right on perfectly placed pockets. Catch a breath at a hueco, then head slightly left and wander up the face to anchors.
content.location: Two bolt lines right of Tatanka

content.description: This route has amazing movement and flow.  It's fairly continuous but most of the harder moves are near the bolts.   The first bolt is about 25 feet up at the top of the huecos.    You might find a huge stick clip here, but you can also place a stopper at the bottom of the huecos.   Climb up through the huecos and at the first bolt head left.   Find a way to reach the jugs up left and angle back right to clip the 2nd bolt.   If you can hang out here, you might be able to sling a chickenhead between the bolts.   Continue up to reach a small overhang and the 3rd bolt.   Climb straight up from here using many sloping holds.   From here keep going up and right passing 1 more bolt until you reach the shuts.
content.protection: 4 bolts, shuts.  Take a couple stoppers and some smaller cams 1" or less.
content.location: From the approach trail on the left side of the cliff, this route is about 30 feet to the right from the point where the trail meets the cliff.   Look for a cluster of huecos low on the wall.

content.description: Start to the right of the first bolt, climb up and Left and enter the crux at the third bolt.  Mono, crimp rail, reach up to pinch.  Amazing.  Moderate climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Orange Wall, next route to the Right from Territorial Pissings (also a great route)

content.description: Climb up the heavily textured rock to reach the mail slots.  Reach out right to clip the second bolt.   From here, head up and right doing some cool moves to gain the top of the overhanging flake.  Clip the 3rd bolt and head up on to the slab and clip the 4th bolt.   Find a way to get through this very thin section to reach the shuts (crux).
content.location: From the approach trail, head right.   Just after passing a 5.8 and 2 10's that start from a high ledge, you'll come to an obvious overhanging corner with 2 huge mail slots about 15 feet up.

content.description: The meat of this route is at the bottom. You can start below the first bolt (a good hold broke here while we were on it, so it is probably a bit harder), or ~6 ft to the left. Clip the only two bolts on the route, and pump your way through some typical New River Gorge not-really-crack-climbing. After this, enjoy easier gear protected climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Far left end of Orange Wall, right of Tatanka and Rock Jihad. Very distinct 20 ft crack at the bottom

content.description: Five bolts of steep jughauling lead into an excellent splitter crack.
content.protection: Five bolts, plus lots of fingers-sized gear, plus recently-installed anchors.
content.location: Toward the right end of Orange Wall; you cannot miss this route.

content.description: If you're at this crag, this climb is worth checking out.   Start at an overhanging section of white rock.  Climb up to reach the first bolt (crux).   You can get some gear in the horizontals before the first bolt.   Continue up and slightly right aiming for the second bolt.   Clip it, reach up to the ledge and traverse left to clip the shuts.
content.protection: 2 bolts, shuts.   A few small cams (1.5" or less).
content.location: From the approach trail, head about 150 yards to the left.   You'll pass a cliff break down, but keep going, the rock will appear again.   It's worth walking over here for this route and it's neighbor.

content.description: Start toward a small ledge wth a chimney at its back corner.  Don't worry, you don't have to climb the chimney!  Move left along a horizontal with small, slippery feet, before heading straight up on friable edges.  Around the fourth bolt is an obvious crux through a blank section up to the back of a roof.  Above this roof is easier, more featured climbing on sloping jugs.
content.protection: 7 bolts to anchors (the guidebook says 5.  LIES!)
content.location: This route is a few hundred feet to the right of the Tatanka area, and climbs a face just left of a 5.8 corner.

content.description:
Nothing forgetful about this route!

Start on an easy layback passing the first bolt. Pull two small roofs on good holds to a bad rest. A mini crux getting over the third bolt with a long lock off or deadpoint to a crimp rail. Moderate climbing for 2 more bolts to a good rest before the business. The final 30 feet or so start with a boulder problem on small but very positive crimps ending in a slot to clip a bolt. Two more bolts of easier but still focus needed climbing to a final pumpy rest before the last few feet of NRG slab smack down at the anchors.
content.protection: 8 bolts, bolt anchor, one drop in, one carabiner
content.location: A few paces left of Hazmat. Look for the obvious left facing flake with some black rock that goes about 15 feet up.

content.description: Quintessential 5.11 NRG sport climbing. Climb some crumbly rock getting off the ground to the black tar section. Traverse left under the roof to a small ledge and a stance then get ready for 50 more feet of engaging face climbing. Classic lock offs on decent edges between blank sections of rock with a crux somewhere in the middle. A few jugs scattered throughout offer some rests and keep the grade relatively moderate.
content.location: Look for a giant black spot of rock under a roof and start slightly left of it.
